--- Derek James <djames@...> wrote:

> I think I've brought this up before, but instead of rummaging through the
> archives I thought I'd just bring it back up.
> 
> I really would like to have a suite of benchmarks that allow us to test a
> new idea or particular implementation against.  It seems to me that many
> domains are idiosyncratic and difficult to reproduce (if the author has not
> provided the source code).
> 
> I figure we all test our initial implementations out on XOR, but it's very
> trivial.  Double pole balancing seems like a great initial entry into a
> benchmark suite, but I guess I'm looking for at least 4-5 more domains like
> DPB that are complex enough to be able to draw some conclusions from, but
> simple enough to implement fairly rapidly and transparently.  Are there
> domains from classic machine learning that are suitable?  Such as the
> Traveling Salesman problem?  It would be nice to have a range of tasks, such
> as:
> 
> 1) control

The code, in C, for a very good control problem, can be downloaded from the ANNEvolve
site.  I'm referring to SailChallenge.  It is well documented, and I'm available to
answer questions.

Mitchell Timin

<snip>



Mitchell Timin

I'm proud of http://ANNEvolve.sourceforge.net.  If you want to write software, or articles, or do testing, or research for ANNEvolve, let me know.
